skill.name: remote-system-maintenance
skill.description: This skill should be used when performing maintenance or diagnostics on remote Linux systems. Triggers on "remote server", "Linux maintenance", "Ubuntu cleanup", "Debian", "disk space", "apt cleanup", "journal vacuum", "snap cleanup", "system diagnostics". Provides structured three-phase checklists with quantification.

security_audit.summary: This is a prompt-based skill containing only Markdown instructions. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or filesystem access beyond reading its own file. The described commands are standard Ubuntu/Debian system administration operations for legitimate maintenance purposes.

content.value_statement: Remote Linux system maintenance requires structured checklists and documentation. This skill provides three-phase diagnostics with quantified cleanup steps for Ubuntu and Debian servers.
actual_capabilities: Run three-phase diagnostics (system state, logs, packages)
Execute seven-stage cleanup sequence (apt, journalctl, snap)
Identify disk space recovery opportunities (300 MB to 2 GB)
Generate structured maintenance logs with before/after metrics
Remove disabled snap revisions for space recovery
Provide follow-up recommendations for ongoing maintenance
limitations: Requires SSH access to remote servers
Skill provides guidance only - user must execute commands
Cannot automate multi-server maintenance without user approval

use_cases.title: Quick server cleanup
use_cases.description: Run structured diagnostics and cleanup on production Ubuntu servers with documented results.

use_cases.title: Disk space recovery
use_cases.description: Recover disk space using journal vacuum, snap cleanup, and apt cache purging.

use_cases.title: Remote server health checks
use_cases.description: Diagnose remote development servers and document maintenance actions taken.

prompt_templates.title: Basic cleanup
prompt_templates.prompt: Clean up disk space on my remote Ubuntu server

prompt_templates.title: With context
prompt_templates.prompt: Production server is low on disk space. Run diagnostics and cleanup.

prompt_templates.title: Full maintenance
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform full system maintenance on my remote Debian server including diagnostics, package updates, and cleanup.

prompt_templates.title: Snap-specific
prompt_templates.prompt: My Ubuntu server has many disabled snap revisions consuming disk space. Help me identify and remove them.

output_examples.input: Clean up disk space on my remote Ubuntu server
output: - apt update and upgrade: 12 packages updated
- snap cleanup: 1.2 GB freed (4 disabled revisions)

best_practices: Always document initial state before making changes to quantify improvements
Run diagnostics phases in order (system, logs, packages) for complete assessment
Generate structured logs for team sharing and maintenance history
anti_patterns: Skipping the documentation step - loses valuable before/after context
Running cleanup without diagnostics - may miss root causes
Using snap remove without --revision flag - keeps old revisions

faq.question: Which Linux distributions are supported?
faq.answer: The skill is designed for Ubuntu and Debian systems. Commands like apt, journalctl, and snap are specific to these distributions.

faq.question: How much disk space can this recover?
faq.answer: Typical recovery ranges from 500 MB to 2+ GB. Journal vacuuming recovers 300-600 MB and snap cleanup can recover 500 MB to 2 GB.

faq.question: Does this skill execute commands automatically?
faq.answer: The skill provides structured guidance and checklists. The user or AI assistant must execute commands on the remote server via SSH.

faq.question: Is my data safe during maintenance?
faq.answer: The skill only removes cache files, old logs, and unused packages. User data in /home and /var is never affected by these cleanup operations.

faq.question: What if a cleanup command fails?
faq.answer: The skill documents all actions and errors. Failed commands are noted in the log. Some failures may require manual intervention or server reboot.

faq.question: How is this different from running apt manually?
faq.answer: The skill provides a structured three-phase approach with documentation. It ensures complete cleanup including snap revisions and journal files that apt alone does not handle.
